children.subject: Fri Dec 13. Final Project Write up Due, http://www-inst.eecs.berkeley.edu/~cs194-126/fa16/
What is the final exam slot for this class? It has a weird lecture time so I can't actually tell from http://schedule.berkeley.edu/examf.html

You'd think given their budget Jacobs wouldn't have to charge students taking classes in it for access, but I guess this isn't the even the first way Jacobs Hall has been a complete and utter disappointment...
I agree, and in general you'd think Berkeley wouldn't make us pay twice for classes.

FYI:

Cost:

Jacobs Hall access is necessary for this course, which requires a $75/semester MakerPass. Students are additionally responsible for the cost of parts and materials in the labs and projects, which can run into the hundreds of dollars.

history.content:
Update: course webpage is up: http://www-inst.eecs.berkeley.edu/~cs194-126/fa16/

Note: CS 194-126 does count towards the 20 units of CS upper div units

You will learn all about rapid prototyping real boards milled on an othermill.  It will be 1/2 half lectures/labs and 1/2 project.  You will write hardware generators in software for circuits allowing ultimate parameterization and scalability and ease of use. The goal is to design circuit boards at the speed of the milling of the boards and to not just design one board but a family of boards.  You need to be able to program so we have requirements of 61a-c or equiv as prereqs.  It's good if you have some EE courses like 16a as background but it's not strictly necessary.

Blurb

This class introduces computational techniques useful for the design and fabrication of PCBs and explores software compilation of high level descriptions of embedded systems into circuit boards and software ready to be milled on desktop mills.  This software defined hardware technique dramatically raises the level of description making easy things easy and hard things much more possible, and most importantly makes PCBs much more accessible to CS students.  Topics include: circuit basics, microcontrollers, embedded programming, milling, assembly and soldering of PCBs.  The class is half lecture/labs and half instructor advised student projects.

background

o programming: CS 61a/b/c 

o ee: ee 16a/b/40 

Terms

software interfaces to circuit components

beginning hobbyist

correct by construction and self-adjusting

software perspective of pcb

system level embedded

circuit board basics

Lectures


01 Introduction -- 1 day -- week 1

02 Basic Embedded Systems + mBED -- 2 days -- week 2

03 Basic PCBs and Soldering -- 1 day -- week 3

03 PCB milling, assembly, and soldering -- 1 day

04 Stanza programming language -- 1 day -> stanza lab -- week 4

04 Basic JITPCB  (or SW defined HW) -- 1 day

05 Basic Circuit design -- 2 days -- week 5

06 Expert JITPCB -- 2 days -- week 6

07 Sensors and Actuators -- 2 days -- week 7

08 Advanced Debugging -- 1 day -- week 8

09 Projects -- 1 day

09 Advanced Stanza -- 1 day

10 proposals

11 meetings

12 presentations

13 meetings

14 presentations

15 meetings

16 meetings

17 finals week

Labs

Solder + spec +  app + fab + driver + gspec


02 Breadboard << basic-circuits + basic-embedded

03 JITPCB canned project (spec + fab) << basic-jitpcb + pcb-milling

04 Solder premilled board (solder) << basic-pcb + stanza

05 Stanza << stanza

06 JITPCB programming (app) <<  basic-embedded + debugging

07 JITPCB full design (spec + app) << expert-jitpcb, debugging

08 JITPCB physical design (driver + gspec) << fab + expert-jitpcb
